cards.front:
A 60-year-old female presents with a tearing sensation in her lower back. Her skin is sweaty, and she is tachycardic. The EMT should suspect:

A. acute pancreatitis.
B. strangulated hernia.
C. kidney stones.
D. aortic aneurysm.
See Pathophysiology

The principal symptom in both infectious and noninfectious gastroenteritis is:

A. vomiting.
B. dysuria.
C. diarrhea.
D. high fever.
See Pathophysiology

Your patientâ€™s past medical history includes hypertension, congestive heart failure, diabetes, and seizures. Today, he presents with signs of acute renal failure. Which of his medical problems MOST likely caused this?

A. Hypertension
B. Seizures
C. Heart failure
D. Diabetes
See Pathophysiology

Most patients with abdominal pain prefer to:

A. sit fully upright because it helps relax the abdominal muscles.
B. lie on their side with their knees drawn into the abdomen.
C. lie in a supine position with their knees in a flexed position.
D. sit in a semi-Fowler position with their knees slightly bent.
See Patient Assessment
cards.back: lie on their side with their knees drawn into the abdomen.

cards.front:
Erosion of the protective layer of the stomach or duodenum secondary to overactivity of digestive juices results in:

A. ileus.
B. cholecystitis.
C. appendicitis.
D. an ulcer.
See Pathophysiology

The MOST common and significant complication associated with an acute abdomen is:

A. internal bleeding.
B. high fever.
C. peritonitis.
D. severe pain.
See Pathophysiology

Pain that radiates to the right lower quadrant from the umbilical area, nausea and vomiting, and lack of appetite are MOST indicative of:

A. gastroenteritis.
B. appendicitis.
C. pancreatitis.
D. cholecystitis.
See Pathophysiology

Which of the following organs assists in the filtration of blood, serves as a blood reservoir, and produces antibodies?

A. Spleen
B. Kidneys
C. Pancreas
D. Liver
See Anatomy and Physiology

Which of the following conditions is more common in women than in men?

A. Hepatitis
B. Cystitis
C. Cholecystitis
D. Pancreatitis
See Pathophysiology

Which of the following organs lies in the retroperitoneal space?

A. Liver
B. Pancreas
C. Gallbladder
D. Spleen
See Anatomy and Physiology

The kidneys help to regulate blood pressure by:

A. accommodating a large amount of blood volume.
B. eliminating toxic waste products from the body.
C. removing sodium and water from the body.
D. retaining key electrolytes, such as potassium.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: removing sodium and water from the body.

cards.front:
Chronic renal failure is a condition that:

A. occurs from conditions such as dehydration.
B. causes dehydration from excessive urination.
C. is often caused by hypertension or diabetes.
D. can be reversed with prompt treatment.
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: is often caused by hypertension or diabetes.

cards.front:
A strangulated hernia is one that:

A. can be pushed back into the body cavity to which it belongs.
B. is reducible if surgical intervention occurs within 2 hours.
C. spontaneously reduces without any surgical intervention.
D. loses its blood supply due to compression by local tissues.
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: loses its blood supply due to compression by local tissues.

cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding the acute abdomen is correct?

A. The parietal peritoneum is typically the first abdominal layer that becomes inflamed or irritated.
B. The most common cause of an acute abdomen is inflammation of the gallbladder and liver.
C. The initial pain associated with an acute abdomen tends to be vague and poorly localized.
D. An acute abdomen almost always occurs as the result of blunt trauma to solid abdominal organs.
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: The initial pain associated with an acute abdomen tends to be vague and poorly localized.

cards.front:
Which of the following organs would MOST likely bleed profusely if injured?

A. Appendix
B. Gallbladder
C. Stomach
D. Liver
See Anatomy and Physiology

Esophageal varices MOST commonly occur in patients who:

A. consume a lot of alcohol.
B. have weak immune systems.
C. have uncontrolled diabetes.
D. have a history of esophagitis.
See Pathophysiology

Solid abdominal organs include the:

A. stomach and small intestine.
B. urinary bladder, colon, and ureters.
C. gallbladder and large intestine.
D. spleen, kidneys, and pancreas.
See Anatomy and Physiology

The parietal peritoneum lines the:

A. surface of the abdominal organs.
B. retroperitoneal space.
C. walls of the abdominal cavity.
D. lungs and chest cavity.
See Pathophysiology

Pain that may be perceived at a distant point on the surface of the body, such as the back or shoulder, is called:

A. referred pain.
B. remote pain.
C. visceral pain.
D. radiating pain.
See Pathophysiology

Which of the following is characteristic of peptic ulcer disease (PUD)?

A. Symptom relief after taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
B. Sharp pain that is typically located in both lower abdominal quadrants
C. The passage of bright red blood in the stool or coughing up blood
D. Burning or gnawing stomach pain that subsides immediately after eating
See Pathophysiology
cards.back: Burning or gnawing stomach pain that subsides immediately after eating
